Name: LINALYL ACETATE
Description: 3,7-dimethylocta-1,6-dien-3-yl acetate is a monoterpenoid that is the acetate ester of linalool. It forms a principal component of the essential oils from bergamot and lavender. It is an acetate ester and a monoterpenoid. It is functionally related to a linalool.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Koukos PK et al; J Agric Food Chem 48: 1266-8 (2000) (2) Shah WA et al; Nat Prod Res 27:1023-7 (2013) (3) Mohammadpour H et al; Jundishapur J Nat Pharm Prod 7:50-5 (2012) (4) Carrasco A et al; Planta Med. Epub PMID:26441063 Oct 4, 2015 (2015) (5) Barkatullah et al; Molecules 20:4735-45 (2015) (6) Oboh G et al; J Oleo Sci 63:373-81 (2014) (7) Dtahl E; Planta Med 50:157-60 (1984) (8) OECD; SIDS Initial Assessment Report For SIAM 14, Linalyl Acetate (CAS No. 115-95-7), March 2002. Available from, as of Nov 19, 2015: https://www.chem.unep.ch/irptc/sids/OECDSIDS/115957.pdf
plant_concentrations.Value: Linalyl acetate was qualitatively identified as a component of the twig and needle oils of the Balkan pine (Pinus peuce)(1). Linalyl acetate is 33% of essential oil of Skimmia laureola growing wild in Jammu and Kashmir, India(2). Linalyl acetate is 4.8% of essential oil of Cuminum cyminum L collected from Alborz Mountain, Iran(3). Lavandula angustifolia essential oil, grown in southeast Spain, contained 21-36% linalyl acetate(4). Linalyl acetate is 50.5% of essential oil of Skimmia laureola leaves collected in Patrak, Pakistan(5). Lemon peels (Citrus limon), collected from Akure main market, Nigeria contained 1.48% linalyl acetate(6). The essential oil from Thymus praecox ssp. arcticus, grown in Iceland contained 70% linalyl acetate(7). Linalyl acetate is 43.6, 26.8 and 45% of essential oil concentrations of Lavandula angustifolia, Salvia desoleana Atzei and Bergamot, respectively(8).

environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: An estimated BCF of 180 was calculated in fish for linalyl acetate(SRC), using a log Kow of 3.93(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is high(SRC).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) OECD; SIDS Initial Assessment Report For SIAM 14, Linalyl Acetate (CAS No. 115-95-7), March 2002. Available from, as of Nov 19, 2015: https://www.chem.unep.ch/irptc/sids/OECDSIDS/115957.pdf
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: Linalyl acetate, present at 100 mg/L, reached 75% of its Theoretical BOD in 4 weeks using an activated sludge inoculum at 30 mg/L and the Japanese MITI test(1).

logP.References: Griffin S et al; Environ Health Perspect 107: 481-7 (1999)

mechanism_of_action.Value: In a preliminary experiment, ... lavender essential oil relaxed vascular smooth muscle. Thus, the/se/  ... experiments were designed to investigate the relaxation mechanism of linalyl acetate as the major ingredient of lavender essential oil in rabbit carotid artery specimens. Linalyl acetate produced sustained and progressive relaxation during the contraction caused by phenylephrine. The relaxation effect of linalyl acetate at a concentration near the EC50 was partially but significantly attenuated by nitroarginine as an inhibitor of nitric oxide synthase, 1H-(1,2,4)oxadiazolo(4,3-a)quinoxaline-1-one as an inhibitor of guanylyl cyclase, or by the denudation of endothelial cells. In specimens without endothelium, the phenylephrine-induced contraction and phosphorylation of myosin light chain (MLC) were significantly attenuated after the pretreatment with linalyl acetate. The relaxation caused by linalyl acetate in the endothelium-denuded specimens was clearly inhibited by calyculin A as an inhibitor of MLC phosphatase, although not by ML-9 as an inhibitor of MLC kinase. Furthermore, suppression of the phenylephrine-induced contraction and MLC phosphorylation with linalyl acetate was canceled by the pretreatment with calyculin A. These results suggest that linalyl acetate relaxes the vascular smooth muscle through partially activation of nitric oxide/cyclic guanosine monophosphate pathway, and partially MLC dephosphorylation via activating MLC phosphatase.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ The sedative properties of the essential oil of Lavender (Lavandula angustifolia Miller) and of its main constituents--linalool and linalyl acetate--were investigated in mice followed up in a series of experimental procedures. The significant decrease in the mobility of female and male laboratory animals under standardized experimental conditions is found to be closely dependent on the exposure time to the drugs. Nevertheless after an injection of caffeine into mice a hyperactivity was observed which was reduced to nearly a normal mobility only by inhalation of these fragrance drugs. In particular the correlation of the mobility of the animals to linalool in serum is experimentally proven, thus furnishing evidence of the aromatherapeutical use of herbal pillows employed in folk medicine since ancient times in order to facilitate falling asleep or to minimize stressful situations of man.[Buchbauer G et al; Z Naturforsch

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Letizia CS et al; Food Chem Toxicol 41 (7): 965-76 (2003)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ Male and female Sprague-Dawley rats (5/sex/dose) received a single i.p. injection of 1120, 1590, 2240, 3160 or 4470 mg/kg linalyl acetate in corn oil. The initial body weights of the rats ranged from 233 to 297 g. Mortality and/or systemic observations were recorded 1, 3 and 6 h post dose and subsequently once daily for 14 days. Mortality and moribundity were recorded twice daily. Gross necropsy was performed on all animals. No deaths were observed at the three lowest dose levels; 7/10 deaths were observed at 3160 mg/kg and 10/ 10 deaths were observed at 4470 mg/kg. The combined LD50 was calculated to be 2864 mg/kg (95% C.I. 2414- 3399 mg/kg; the LD50 in male rats was calculated to be 2778 mg/kg (95% C.I. 2246-3435) and the LD50 in female rats was calculated to be 2984 mg/kg (95% C.I. 2293-3884). Clinical signs observed in all dose groups included depression, ataxia, urine stains, rough coat and soft feces. Labored respiration, wheezing, hunched position, and red stains on the nose and/or eyes were observed at the two highest dose groups; prostration, tremors and lacrimination were also observed at the highest dose level. Necropsy revealed discolored lungs, thickened lobes in the liver and a thick white material adhered to and covering the liver and spleen. In addition, discolored liver, kidneys and adrenals and abnormal contents in the intestines, abdominal cavity and thoracic cavity were also observed in the animals that died during the study

In a test with miniature swines, application of 0.05 g linalyl acetate under a patch for 48 hours /caused/ no irritation ... .

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ Linalyl acetate was tested in a 90-day study. The test material was a mixture of materials containing linalyl acetate (24.2 mg/kg), linalyl isobutyrate and geranyl acetate. The materials were blended in the proportion of their use levels and incorporated into the basal diet to provide 100 mg/kg bodyweight of the mixture. Each diet was fed ad libitum to a group of 20 rats (10/sex) with initial body weights of 50-70 g. Records were made of physical appearance and behavior and the efficiency of food utilization (EFU) was calculated for each group. After 12 weeks, urinalysis was conducted on 6 animals (3/sex) and blood hemoglobin levels were determined. All animals were sacrificed after 90 days and gross necropsy was carried out. Blood hemoglobin, urinalysis, body weight, liver and kidney weights, food intake, EFU, behavior and appearance were normal in the males. Growth, food intake and food utilization were slightly depressed in the females.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Letizia CS et al; Food Chem Toxicol 41 (7): 965-76 (2003)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/ To determine co-carcinogenic activity, groups of mice were given dermal applications of linalyl acetate alone or with benzo-a-pyrene (BaP). Linalyl acetate, 3 mg in 0.1 mL acetone, was tested alone and was also tested with simultaneous applications of 1 and 5 ug BaP. Solutions were applied to the clipped backs of 20 female ICR/Ha Swiss mice/group, 3 times a week, for the duration ofthe study (460 days). Control groups received the carcinogen alone, or the solvent alone or remained untreated. Mice were observed regularly and tumors were recorded. Those greater than 1 mm in diameter were counted and charted regularly. Only tumors persisting for 30 days or more were counted in the cumulative totals. Mice with tumors that appeared grossly to be carcinomas were sacrificed 2 months after the tumor was classified as malignant. All animals were necropsied and tumors were confirmed histologically. No carcinogenic activity was observed when linalyl acetate was administered alone; no co-carcinogenic activity was observed when it was administered with 1 ug BaP. Weak co-carcinogenic activity was observed when linalyl acetate was administered with 5 ug BaP.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/ Linalyl acetate was tested in a carcinogenicity assay in mice (A/He). Animals received 3 times per week an /ip/ injection ... with linalyl acetate at 200 or 1000 mg/kg (total exposure 8 weeks, total 24 injections). Total observation time was 24 weeks. Control animals were included in the study design. Full histopathology was performed on the lungs only. Liver, kidney, spleen, thymus, intestine and salivary and endocrine glands were investigated macroscopically. No increase in tumor bearing animals was reported ... .

The effect was more severe in mice of aged 6-8 weeks (up to 100% reduction) than in mice of 6 months (up to 81% reduction). ...

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development; Screening Information Data Set for LINALYL ACETATE (115-95-7) p.53 (March 2002). Available from, as of July 14, 2008: https://www.chem.unep.ch/irptc/sids/OECDSIDS/sidspub.html
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Neurotoxicity/ The local anesthetic activity of the essential oil of Lavandula angustifolia /(linalyl acetate, purity 43.6%)/ is evaluated. ... This essential oil and pure linalyl acetate (97%; 0.01-10 ug/mL) were able to drastically reduce, in a dose-dependent manner, the electrically evoked contractions of rat phrenic-hemidiaphragm. This finding excludes antimuscarinic activity of linalyl acetate. ... A rabbit conjunctival reflex test treatment with a solution of the same test substances (30-2500 ug/mL administered in the conjunctival sac) results in a dose-dependent increase in the number of stimuli necessary to provoke the reflex (ie suppression of the reflex). ... The local anesthetic activity is not caused by antimuscarinic activity of these compounds, but is suggested to be related to effects on the Na+ and/or Ca+2 channels.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Letizia CS et al; Food Chem Toxicol 41 (7): 965-76 (2003)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /GENOTOXICITY/ An in vitro unscheduled DNA synthesis (UDS) assay was conducted in primary rat hepatocytes at doses up to 300 nL/mL. The positive control was dimethylbenz (a) anthracene at 3 nL/mL and 10 nL/mL. No increases in net nuclear grain counts were noted. Linalyl acetate did not show genotoxic potential based on the negative results in the in vitro UDS assay.

/GENOTOXICITY/ The mutagenic ... effects of ...  linalyl acetate ...  were evaluated by the bacterial reverse mutation assay on Salmonella typhimurium TA98 and TA100, and on Escherichia coli WP2uvrA strains. ... Linalyl acetate induced a statistically significant increase in the number of revertant colonies in WP2uvrA, both with and without S-9 mixture. ...

Unscheduled DNA synthesis (UDS) was measured by electronically counting nuclear grains and subtracting the average number of grains in 3 adjacent nuclear sized cytoplasmic areas. ... Linalyl acetate was not shown to be clastogenic under the test conditions.

/ALTERNATIVE and IN VITRO TESTS/ In a preliminary experiment, ... lavender essential oil relaxed vascular smooth muscle. Thus, /these/  ... experiments were designed to investigate the relaxation mechanism of linalyl acetate as the major ingredient of lavender essential oil in rabbit carotid artery specimens. Linalyl acetate produced sustained and progressive relaxation during the contraction caused by phenylephrine. The relaxation effect of linalyl acetate at a concentration near the EC50 was partially but significantly attenuated by nitroarginine as an inhibitor of nitric oxide synthase, 1H-(1,2,4)oxadiazolo(4,3-a)quinoxaline-1-one as an inhibitor of guanylyl cyclase, or by the denudation of endothelial cells. In specimens without endothelium, the phenylephrine-induced contraction and phosphorylation of myosin light chain (MLC) were significantly attenuated after the pretreatment with linalyl acetate. The relaxation caused by linalyl acetate in the endothelium-denuded specimens was clearly inhibited by calyculin A as an inhibitor of MLC phosphatase, although not by ML-9 as an inhibitor of MLC kinase. Furthermore, suppression of the phenylephrine-induced contraction and MLC phosphorylation with linalyl acetate was canceled by the pretreatment with calyculin A. These results suggest that linalyl acetate relaxes the vascular smooth muscle through partially through activation of nitric oxide/cyclic guanosine monophosphate pathway, and partially MLC dephosphorylation via activating MLC phosphatase.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: USEPA/HPVIS; Detailed Chemical Results on 1,6-Octadien-3-ol, 3,7-dimethyl-, acetate (115-95-7): Repeated-Dose Toxicity for Mammalian Health Effects SIDS. Available from, as of July 14, 2008: https://www.epa.gov/hpvis/index.html
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /IMMUNOTOXICITY/ /Linalyl acetate/ was administered intragastrically on a daily basis for 5 days at /3000, 1500, or 750 mg/kg/day in corn oil/ to /female/ B6C3F1 /or CD-1/ mice. A host-resistance assay (Listeria monocytogenes bacterial challenge) was conducted to assess cell-mediate immunity. Humoral immunity was measured by the antibody Plaque-Forming cell (PFC) response to sheep erythrocytes. Cyclophosphamide served as an immunosuppressive positive control agent. ... Increased mortality following challenge with L. monocytogenes was noted at 750 mg/kg. No significant alteration in the PFC response was noted. The increased mortality observed following challenge with L. monocytogenes was not dose-related and therefore considered to be incidental. ... /It was concluded that/ linalyl acetate did not mediate the cell-mediated or humoral immune response.

/IMMUNOTOXICITY/ ... The aim of the present study was to investigate the autoxidation of linalyl acetate and the influence of oxidation on its sensitizing potency. ... Analyses were performed using gas chromatography, nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometry and mass spectrometry. Sensitizing potencies of compounds were determined using the local lymph node assay (LLNA) in mice. ... : Analyses showed that the content of linalyl acetate decreased over time on air exposure and other compounds were formed. Hydroperoxides, an epoxide and an alcohol were identified as oxidation products from linalyl acetate. In the LLNA, linalyl acetate of high purity showed a weak sensitizing potency (EC3 25%). Autoxidation increased the sensitizing potency of linalyl acetate, and a 10 weeks oxidized sample gave an EC3 value of 3.6%. As for linalool, the hydroperoxides were shown to be the oxidation products with the highest sensitizing potency. ... It is concluded that autoxidation of the weakly allergenic linalyl acetate leads to formation of allergenic oxidation products.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development; Screening Information Data Set for LINALYL ACETATE (115-95-7) p.53 (March 2002). Available from, as of July 14, 2008: https://www.chem.unep.ch/irptc/sids/OECDSIDS/sidspub.html
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /OTHER TOXICITY INFORMATION/ The local anesthetic activity of the essential oil of Lavandula angustifolia /(linalyl acetate, purity 43.6%)/ is evaluated. ... This essential oil and pure linalyl acetate (97%; 0.01-10 ug/mL) were able to drastically reduce, in a dose-dependent manner, the electrically evoked contractions of rat phrenic-hemidiaphragm. This finding excludes antimuscarinic activity of linalyl acetate. ... A rabbit conjunctival reflex test treatment with a solution of the same test substances (30-2500 ug/mL administered in the conjunctival sac) results in a dose-dependent increase in the number of stimuli necessary to provoke the reflex (ie suppression of the reflex). ... The local anesthetic activity is not caused by antimuscarinic activity of these compounds, but is suggested to be related to effects on the Na+ and/or Ca+2 channels.

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.1. Nov, 2012. Available from, as of Nov 19, 2015: https://www2.epa.gov/tsca-screening-tools (2) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: Using a structure estimation method based on molecular connectivity indices(1), the Koc of linalyl acetate can be estimated to be 430(SRC). According to a classification scheme(2), this estimated Koc value suggests that linalyl acetate is expected to have moderate mobility in soil.
